cons: The main concern for anyone required to work on an assembly line, day after day, year after year, is the toll it takes on the body. After a certain number of years, if you don't take care of your body through proper nutrition and exercise, it can wear on you and possibly be problematic in your later years. They do provide the benefits of a great medical coverage as well as chiropractic and dental which if used pragmatically, eases this burden. Pay strict attention to the safety procedures in place and you should be able to withstand a full career there.

review_title: Very poor. On road to another bankruptcy.
pros: Huge building, nice workspaces. But often it feels like building is the only selling point that FCA has for new hires.
cons:
FCA has obviously been through a lot - merger, bankruptcy, bankruptcy, scandals, merger, scandals. You got to wonder what the people are like inside the company. 
After a company goes through such ups and downs, any sane, qualified person who can leave the company, does leave the company. Any one who can't, ends up staying and gets exceedingly verse in office politics. People like this make up the majority of company. These are the people you'll have to work with daily - uncooperative, rude, technically incompetent, but excellent in politics and backstabbing. 

Cherry on top is the merger with Fiat. Chrysler is undergoing process changes to align itself with Fiat, and it's a slow chaotic process for companies this large. End result is a terrible poorly managed and operated company, at least for now.  

I just wanted to give a snapshot of FCA employees in this review. The poor public image, horrible product quality, fraud, product delays, lack of good technology, constant product and plan changes, no plans for electric and autonomous vehicles - these are all well known and I don't need to be delved into.

review_title: The people at Chrysler are the BEST
pros: The people at Chrysler are the BEST, and contrary to the posts by some individuals seen here, characteristically  very strong and resilient. There is also a spirit of belonging, and camaraderie at Chrysler unlike any other company - and even (or especially) in these most difficult of times, people help each other and pull together.  It helps to be a small nimble company, with a long history of innovation and invention, and a direct 2-way exchange with senior management.
cons: Sadly Chrysler is in a far worse position than it would have been due to the damage done by Daimler:  Chrysler was irrefutably  the gem of American industry in 1998 and at the pinnacle of Automotive success when it was sold out, and then like the proverbial cash cow, systematically bled dry of cash, quality, and product content. - Fortunately, Cerberus immediately took extreme measures and spent enormous sums to reinstate  quality and the product - putting "Customer First" and "Quality PERIOD".  - So there is now therefore a much better prospect for the long haul - even if it means operating with some new, or radically different business model.

Very high involvement of Head Office in every aspect of the company's day to day running.
The company's ego is very high, management believe that FCA is the most sought after employer everywhere like Italy, and fail to acknowledge anything that points otherwise, like high employee turnover.
Management is only interested in making profits and employee benefits & welfare are not even a consideration to them.

pros: Cannot name any positive comments.
cons: Terrible Employer, no development opportunities, negative selection...

review_title: Chrysler:  A great company being destroyed by government interference.
pros: Carbuilding is an exciting and dynamic business at the leading edge of technology.  Chrysler has always developed the most innovative styling and features, and the most exciting powertrains in the business.  Customers are very loyal and very passionate about their vehicles, and this is felt throughout the company.
cons: Government interference has severely damaged the credit market which is killing the auto industry (and many other businesses).  Chysler is being forced to cut DEEP to reduce costs and it will hurt the product development process going forward.  The US auto industry takes a beating in the liberal media and from many government officials for asking for loans, yet the legislators that created the credit mess by  forcing banks to give loans to unqualified people are allowed to hide behind the scenes.  In the meantime they pass regulations that further add to the cost and complexity of vehicles, often for the benefit of nobody but special interest groups.  Americans need to wake up and speak up to our legislators that US manufacturing will soon be gone if we continue these liberal policies!

pros: Laid back schedule, plenty of inventory
cons: No clear direction and 0 accountability on upper management

review_title: Great school but you must learn how to survive quite quickly
pros: Fiat is probably one of the best "schools" you can find if you have a small experience behind your back. You definitely have to boost your learning speed to survive and perform properly.
cons: The size may become a major con. In some cases each department becomes a company inside the company and mismatching targets between different parts of the company may prevent correct collaboration. Other major con: the HR function disappear as soon as you are in. All your career profile is managed by your n+1, the HR function is just a pro-forma, you won't have scheduled meetings like in other companies and they won't help much in case of shifts to different activities. You must build personal contacts, don't expect to be assessed only on the base of your results.

review_title: The worst company to ever work for
job_title: Production Team Member in Toledo, OH
pros:
Half way descent medical
Not much more
cons:
Where do I start
Management 
Union
Pay 
Benefits
Racist company

job_title: Powertrain Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: You get thrown in front of the bus with no warning as soon as you join, it’s a great way to learn really good life lessons and a way to learn things fast. You will get hit by the bus several times along your journey , however you learn to become a better person and learn a lot. You get great exposure to different groups within the company.
cons:
Lots of politics. Everyone tries to meet unrealistic timelines knowing they will never meet. Management people would rather hear a pleasant lie over harsh truth. It’s all about CYOA. You get hired as contract and lots of politics go into getting hired direct. If you are related to the senior manager, you get hired direct before someone who’s been there a year before you. They will drain the life out of you and throw you down the hole. Good work is never appreciated , they will always remember a mistake you’ve made. 

You want to get ahead at FCA? It’s simple. Don’t do any work, go to meetings , talk crap if it makes sense or not, just be louder than the other person. You can spit out garbage and management will appreciate you over someone who actually does good work but keeps quite.

review_title: Years of mismanagement have finally caught up.
job_title: Engineering Team Leader in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: My local group was great.  Product and work was fun.
cons:
Management was arrogant, overly tactical, and on some levels incompetent.  Decisions were often delayed or feared lest a mistake were made.  Most managers were afraid to make decisions that might cost them their career path or bonus.  And the talk of using Voice of the Customer to drive decisions was hogwash.  It was more like Voice of Upper Management.  Any VoC input that might cost money or went against what engineering management wanted was often ignored.

No thought is given to talent or how to promote it.  Most often, promotions go to friends or often unqualified minorities.  If you were in, you were ok.  The pervasive talent mismanagement has kept a cycle of ineptitude going for many, many years.

job_title: Product Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Work-life balance is great and this is not just my personal impression, other coworkers from different areas think exactly the same. Going from contract to direct took me 1.5 years but now the benefits are 1000 times better, low premiums for PPO plan, vision and dental. New 401K match is good, very good. Good prices on company lease cars for someone with a couple years in the U.S. All I can do is speak good of this great company and working out of Chrysler Tech Center is really motivating!
cons: Working as a contract can be disappointing. Still don't get why is that needed or at least why FCA works with 50+ staffing companies where benefits and salaries can be so uneven among them. I've seen people leaving because they never got converted to direct employees but are working for another OEM now.

review_title: Decent environment for entry level engineer
job_title: Product Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros:
-Initial offer had a decent salary considering the good benefits. Accepted salary negotiation to reach a well above market value salary.
-Automatic contributions to 401k and matching
-Okay healthcare options
-Friendly, goal driven environment
-Will send you to training for various softwares
-Good career opportunities taking the place of people who leave for GM and Ford...
-Building is nice with a big cafeteria and large windows
cons:
-The work life balance isn't perfect. It's a bit up and down depending on where a program is in development.
-The technical prowess isn't as high as I expected it to be. Many experienced people have left to GM or Ford for pay raises leaving a hole in talent. Too much emphasis is placed on benchmarking other vehicles that are assumed to be good rather than spending time to do original, thoughtful design.
-The design studio has a much better working environment. More ergonomic setup, open layout workplace, etc.

review_title: Too much middle management CYA instead of best decisions for company
job_title: Senior Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros:
Many very competent engineers with hands-on experience and also very talented designers. 
Great ideas and products when not MCMed to death.
cons:
Middle management was too worried about their little area and their bonus to make the best decisions for the company, but I blame upper management for setting up the platforms the way they did to cause the mess. 
When upper management was doing things right, middle managers were failing to follow through or implement. They were too worried about spending a buck or two to provide necessary tools and keep very good people.
Upper management got their hands into the styling of vehicles when none of them were qualified to do so, taking what often started as a great design and completely screwing it up. "Take the front of concept one, put it on the back of concept two, and add a little swoopy character line right there".

review_title: I didn't listen to the previous reviews
job_title: Marketing Manager in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: The only good thing about working at FCA is the pay.
cons: I didn't listen to the previous reviews, thinking it couldn't be THAT bad. I was wrong. People don't leave jobs, they leave managers. There is a vast lack of leadership at FCA. Majority of the people here are miserable, they only stay because it pays well. Most of the people here are defensive and ready to throw you under the bus in a heartbeat. FCA and its leadership team only cares about meeting sales goals. They do not care about you, your career, your happiness, or your work-life balance. I met so many people here that didn't know the names of their coworkers' loved ones. There is very little humanity at FCA. I have never written a Glassdoor review but I felt it was necessary to tell any prospective job-seeker the truth about this place. For your own sanity, pass on this job and find a company that actually cares about its employees.

review_title: Stable Company, but many changes have happened recently - Cautiously neutral outlook
job_title: Operations Manager in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Great company car selection. Stable work if you want to do your job for a long time. OK benefits. There are parts of the company with simply amazing managers that care(I stress "parts" - see cons).
cons: New Leadership since Sergio's departure is lackluster and headcount has increased at the top and has dwindled at the bottom. This has stalled innovation and the "musical chairs" has ended leaving many company lifers (20+ years) coasting their careers in key positions. This coincided with a pay freeze - I have more responsibility with the same pay year over year. The smart people can see the writing on the wall - 3 Directors have quit in the past 6 months to go to dealers. It is very easy to hit a dead end with a VP/Director that doesn't care - be careful what positions you take.

pros: The best part about working at Chrysler Canada is being able to work with the many great people i work with. Considering i'm a TPT, this job is a great opportunity for me because it helps me pay for my school and learn basic life skills that i will use for the rest of my life.
cons: The only con i can think of is the fact that (since im a TPT and it's not on our contract anymore) if we don't work 40 hours during the week, we don't qualify for the time and a half pay on saturdays (when theyre scheduled... which is very very often) which would help benefit us (the ones who pay for school, apartment and living like me) so much because it's almost impossible to do 40 hours a week as well as be a full-time student. But otherwise, there is no cons i can think of.

review_title: One heck of a roller coaster ride
pros: Pay and benefits are good, the Auburn Hills facilities are great, and working in the automotive industry can be challenging and exciting with all of the new developments.
cons: Corporate culture and morale have deteriorated over the last 30 years.  The environment before the Daimler fiasco was great, although it was somewhat seat-of-the-pants due to the leadership of people like Bob Lutz.  Daimler took all that away and left us for dead.  Cerberus took a bad situation, made it worse, and bankrupt the company.  Under Sergio things are looking up, but there is a very high level of stress and morale is low.

review_title: Needs to keep pace with competitors
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Great camaraderie among some groups. Many solid and experienced people who have been through many ups and downs over the years, but have stuck with the company to help see it get back on its feet. Small size of departments creates opportunities for increased responsibility and advancement, but also can be high stress with little support. Auburn Hills is a nice area to work and live versus other Detroit area options.
cons: Outdated and demotivating performance review process makes any advancement and compensation improvement goals difficult to plan for and achieve on an individual level. Benefits and compensation continually seem to be shifting and out of step with competitors. FCA has frequently been in the news recently for negative reasons which have reduced morale internally. Senior leadership turnover rate is high as a result. Turnover at lower ranks is also increasing as good employees seek greener pastures.

job_title: Electrical Product Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Flexible work hours, Good benefits,  allowed to switch jobs every 24 month provided you don't have a poor performance rating. Company lease car program for salaried employees can be a good deal on some cars. Very nice building, on site gym.
cons: Performance rating system uses a forced distribution. Upper management requires 20% of engineering salaried employees to be rated as needs improvement every year. Work at home is highly frowned upon. CIE (Chrysler institute of Engineering ) graduates are placed on the fast path to upper management regardless of performance.Many seem to be Exec offspring. Turnover rate of engineering staff has become a big problem , along with poor overall morale. Beware of Human Resources at this company since they are nothing but a upper management henchmen.

review_title: Preferential treatment and discrimination rampant at FCA
job_title: Product Engineer in Rochester Hills, MI
pros:
-Most coworkers although unhappy working there were nice and professional all the time.
-Nice buildings with all shops and facilities.
cons:
FCA has no regard for professional high achievers. Unless you have a close and personal relationship with your manager, expect to get knocked down in your performance rating and watch the lowest performers rise high year after year. Zero growth prospects offered during my last 9 years of service with the company.

Engineers do 90% of clerical paperwork job and 10% “real” engineering. I tried to raise this issue several times with the management as it affected the quality of the products over a longer term.  Unfortunately the culture is so stiff that management won’t listen to or act.

pros: Pay is good when you start. Some decent deals on company leases. Facility has some nice perks (gym, convenience shops, coffee shops, pretty good cafeterias).
cons:
The stupid stuff first. The walk from car to desk is ridiculous, especially if you don’t drive an FCA vehicle. The building is musty and feels a bit 80s tacky. Good luck finding a stall to go number 2. Good luck finding a conference room. The chairs are uncomfortable everywhere. 

The important stuff. There are a few intelligent people here. Most are in middle management roles. They will not speak up for fear of losing that role. Otherwise, there a boatload of mostly untalented contractors who don’t care, or untalented salaries workers who are clueless. This isn’t an engineering company, it’s a company that contracts almost everything because they can’t do it themselves. They build vehicles in spite of themselves. There is a culture of go fast, go now. This is often before any planning or structure is in place, causing significant rework and confusion. Training is non-existent. Products are VERY hit or miss.

review_title: It's a stepping stone, not a destination
job_title: Assembly Line Worker in Windsor, ON
pros: Good pay, if you're good at your job and don't cause downtime most higher-ups won't care if you listen to your phone so depending on how social you are that's up to 8 hours of podcast/tutorial/audiobook listening time so you can learn while you work, stable hours for the most part (if you're a student). I'll be graduating school with no debt too which is pretty cool
cons: No one really cares about you, sometimes blatant disrespect from other employees and management, most people are courteous but the ones that aren't hardly get disciplined, no one bothers to even ask your name, you're just constantly referred to as a "body" and the only time management really comes to talk to you is to yell or discipline you, don't expect any praise for anything and don't expect anything more than working a very repetitive strenuous job. Good for short term but stay too long and your soul and joy will be sucked out by all the miserable people there

review_title: Overall good but your manager makes the difference
pros: Flexible schedules with work from home available in certain departments. Good benefits even though employee costs and deductibles continue to rise annually. Employee discount on vehicle pricing. Profit sharing when we are successful.
cons: Terrible parking (far from entrances). There is literally not enough parking spaces during periods when the majority aren’t scheduling vacation (full capacity early in the year but better during high vacation periods like spring break or mid summer).  Not enough office space. Some areas are shifting to work pods with people grouped together and away from individual work stations. Very noisy with some suites having no partitions at all. Even in suites having cubicle walls you can hear multiple conversations going on constantly. If you have a cougher or throat clearer a row over, you might as well be sitting in their lap since nothing is muffled. The performance appraisal process is absolutely horrible. Job satisfaction heavily related to who your manager is.

review_title: Work is great! HR is the worst!
pros: Wonderful place to work if you love cars. You have the ability to move around to work on different things and meet a lot of great people.
cons:
Human Resources (HR) are the worst in the industry. They have way too much power in hiring and firing decisions and too often select people that will "get along socially" as opposed to getting the work done. Too many times has top technical talent been turned away despite fervent endorsement from engineering management personnel, all because HR felt that they were too reclusive. Those talents end up getting hired at competitors and end up very successful.

Also, pay and benefits are way below the industry standard. You have to love to work there in order to stay, because you clearly aren't doing it for the money.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: FCA has evolved into an amazing company that has potential for advancement and truly takes care of its employees. The company as a whole has innovative and interesting products in market as well as many years to come with future products.
cons: Like many large global companies it is easy to get lost in the mix and easily forgotten. Get too comfortable in a position and competition is lacking as there are so many layers and divisions globally. Not to much to write in this section as at the end of the day every opportunity is for you/I to create not the company we work for.

job_title: Project Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros:
Very good communication with the groups.  
Great people to work with - everyone wants to do a good job, although this year, and the Fiat announcement (another one - from left field) no one is sure what the exact job is.
Before losing 5,000 people, people are generally happy with the workload they were assigned.
cons:
Everyone is involved, yet no one is responsible.  Lack of ownership of a component/program diminishes personal responsibility in the long run.
Typical large company - everyone looking out for their own interests - the overall good is lost in personal gain/glory.
With the departure of 5,000 - workloads have DOUBLED.  Short-sighted managers still expect the same level of detail, despite the ridiculous burden placed on (typically) hard-working employees.
Morale - when is Cerebus going to "dump and run?"

pros:
High paced work environment with great people. Facility is well supported and a fun place to be. On site gym, mulitple cafeterias with pretty good food (especially helpful in winter when you do not want to trek the mile to your car.)
Plenty of opportunity to grow within the organization or diversify yourself to other functional groups.
cons:
In order to move up, expectations of 55-60 hour work weeks are common. Work/life balance is off the table. 
No urgency to discipline/terminate severe under performers. Seems as though they "do not want to rock the apple cart" yet when raises/promotions are brought up, there is "no money" available. Well there would be plenty to keep high performers around if the organization dealt with poor performers.

review_title: Long hours with little extra compensation make tough times at Chrysler
job_title: Logistics Manager in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Chrysler has great people to work with who are all passionate about their work.   The exciting products Chrysler develops makes the job interesting and fun, yet challenging to accomplish given the current economic climate.  Employees are given a lot of responsibility and can gain a lot of experience in varying functions.  Overall, it was a great experience in good times.
cons: Many of the jobs at Chrysler require long hours to accomplish tasks by deadlines given.  There is no bonus/merit raise structure for great performance and hard work.  Many assignments are understaffed which create a hard environment for getting the job done right.  Training in several areas is non-existent, which causes problems for all employees.

job_title: Quality Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Even as an intern, I was treated with respece and given projects that would be given to any other full time employee. Management cared that I enjoyed my work and was learning, and was always open to providing help. Great learning and growing experience, especially if cars are your passion. Being immersed and interested in the automotive world makes this job far more enjoyable, and management makes a point of involving employees with the product to maintain their interest. Take advantage of the many opportunities Chrysler will throw your way; they are well worth your time.
cons: Chrysler (FCA) is a very large company, which can make integration difficult at times. Learning how to find the right person to talk to or what database to search for what is challenging. As with any large company, there are a wide range of personalities to work with, which can be good or bad. If you live near Headquaters, you will have to drive to find anything fun to do after hours, though Detroit and Ann Arbor are great places to go.

job_title: Product Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Great location, lots of exposure to different areas of automotive engineering. Lots of lessons learned on how to deal with people and how someone can **** you over
cons:
They mostly hire fresh grads like myself straight out of school, afterwards no training at all!! However, 6 months down the line you are expected to know everything. They throw you in different projects and expect you to know everything, when you make a mistake due to lack of training, its your fault.  You have to learn everything the hard way. Very disorganized and lots of politics in management level. 
Time management is horrible. Nothing is planned, they rush and force last minute and throw you under the bus.
As hourly paid contract worker, you are not paid over time but still expected to work Long hours. if the topic of overtime compensation is brought up, managements response is "No one asked you to work more than 40 hours a week"

review_title: Great products/people/resources about to be flushed down the drain
pros: The products that are designed HERE are great and as much OT as you want (even for salaried) is available if you are in a plant. Benefit packages are good as well.
cons: Again, the plants are so busy you pretty much have to work OT. Fiat is pushing its WCM, even though they are dead last in JD power. The Fiat designed products (500, Dart, 200, Cherokee) are not doing so well because they won't listen to Americans. Work-life balance is great if you are at CTC, otherwise it is awful.

job_title: Production Unit Leader in Kokomo, IN
pros:
Outstanding Benefits!! 
1. Excellent 401K match of up to 8% if you invest at least 10% of your base salary.
2. Health Insurance is by far the best I've ever had. 
3. Vision and Dental are pretty good
4. A ton of PERKS including employee vehicle leasing: Able to order and lease a vehicle online and there is NO credit checks, No contract Lease, and the payment is taken directly out of your check.
cons:
1. The upper management are micromanaging fools. They scrutinize every single detail, you can NOT make any decision on your own without them trying to have a hand in it. You will be MICRO MANAGED and you WILL GET STRESSED OUT!!! 
2. There is NO work life to family life balance. YOU WILL LIVE AT WORK. 
3. YOU will work HOLIDAYS even when they are scheduled off!
4. Upper management will not allow supervisors to make decisions without them.

review_title: Engineering reputation is a thing of the past.
job_title: Engineering Supervisor in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: At this time with the company and domestic auto manufacturers fighting for survival, it's hard to come up with a best reason to work for Chrysler.
cons: If someone is looking for hands on engineering work, this is not the company to work for. The majority of hands on engineering work is done by suppliers and contract house. Engineers are typically used as project managers. Engineering is being outsourced to offshore engineering centers which will eventually result in staff reductions in Auburn Hills as well as limited opportunities for those that remain.  Engineering management is still overrun with the good old boy network. If you're not in the network or have someone pulling you along, you're not going anywhere regardless of how good a job you've done. An entitlement mentality for bonus level positions still exists and is demoralizing to lower level employees.  Too many unqualified people in decision making roles. Morale is low as everyone is fearing for their job.

review_title: Management could care less about you at Chrysler.....
pros: They do have some of the best looking trucks on the market.  With their lack of respect for any sort of family life, you do end up getting a lot of hotel points and airline miles if you are in the field.
cons: They have no respect for any personal life.  They want you working 24/7 and have little to no regard for family situations.  They may occasionally make an exception then bring it up against you at a later date.

review_title: Chrysler, not the place the news makes it out to be.
pros: Challenging opportunities, High Tech World Leader in Manufacturing Processes. Leaders in Automation and Robot controls. State of the art design and engineering ant testing. You now travel farther on a gallon of fuel and about one tenth of the pollution as just ten or twenty years ago. You get the chance to be part of a team that is leading the world in new process. There would not be a plant south of Detroit that could make a Car worth driving with out the hard work of over 60 years that the Detroit Big Three did not pioneer for others to follow.
cons: Unfair view of workers by others, The UAW help make this the strong Nation that it is today. Read a little what they and Detroit did for the World during WWII. Detroit the Arsenal of the World. Now the country wants to condemn the UAW

review_title: My experience varies with the supervisor.   Sometimes it's quite good; sometimes not.
pros: The working-level people are great.   They work cohesively and they feel strongly about creating a quality product.  It is nice to develop a product that you are likely to use yourself.
cons: There is an over-emphasis on University-level degrees, particularly the MBA.    Degrees are certainly EXTREMELY helpful in providing knowledge, but they are not the only route to knowledge and skills.  Some jobs are restricted based on having a Master's degree.  Further jobs are restricted to MBAs.

review_title: It's a challenge to excel in marketing in this engineering run company, but there is incredible potential out there!
pros: The company is extremely adaptable and resiliant after its financial distress in recent years, and the company is very hopeful for the future.  The need for young and creative people is overwhelming - those without automotive background may be better positioned than they think!  The building is cavernous with all of the basic amenities, and if having to make a meeting at the other end of the building get ready for a power walk!
cons: While Chrylser is despartely in need of creative minds, it does a poor job at harnessing creativity.  Engineering really runs the show and marketing is often an afterthought.  HR needs considerable improvement - there is a great disconnect between them and the rest of the company.  Don't be turned off by a bad brush with HR, as it is not indicative of the way things work.

pros: New free car every 6 months is awesome and the pay was great. Bonus structure was a difficult to figure out but if you were in a good district you did make good money on it. lots of upward mobility if you were ok with moving a ton.
cons: No work/life balance. Too reliant on the NA market and the pressure was on all the ASM's who were the final part of the company. If the NA market can preform than the company won't be able to preform. Also the lack of hybrid/electric cars did bother me. I don't want to be working for a company that's not trying to be on the cutting edge and they were far too concerned with ICE trucks and SUV's.

review_title: A company in trouble and in need of new direction.
pros: Coworkers at my facility work together as a team and care about the quality of the products that are produced.
cons: Career opportunities within the company are uncertain due to recent downsizings and reorganization of departments. Chrysler has eliminated tuition reimbursement, no longer offers financing for lease vehicles, and sales are down significantly; all these things create a workplace full of people with extremely low morale.  Also, there are the recent talks of either Nissan or GM merging with us, which only attributes to further anxiety for most employees.  All the negativity and rumors makes it extremely hard to stay positive and motivated about coming to work, especially when you don't know what the future holds.  Needless to say, that Company morale is at an all time low right now and top management is not being very forthcoming with details.

review_title: Chrysler Group LLC a good place to work?
pros: During my 15 year employment with Chrysler I was treated fairly. Chrysler gave individuals a great chance for advancement based on a individuals passion, talent and education provided you left the union workforce.
cons: Chrysler is at a volatile point in its existance. Increased competion from rivals carmakers notably for Asian countries (Japan, Korean and soon China) as well  as a weak economy have left American carmakers in a precarious position. I left due to this fact. I'm 35 and currently lack the education to transition to another job with such benefits as well as maintain my current lifestyle. So I found it best to leave get my education while I'm still relatively young.

review_title: The pay was not worth the mental abuse.
job_title: Powertrain Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Its a great place to get experience for your first or second job and learn mental toughness and the fine art of taking abuse.  You will know what you like and don't like to do for a living.
cons: PT is run on fear and intimidation.  The don't develop people or skills, they just use people up until they break and then find fresh meat. You could work 16 hour days (8 hrs of it unpaid of course) and it will not be enough to satisfy your management.  Never a thank you or a "You did a Good Job", just criticism.  If you are not made permanent within the first year, you need to find a new job, because you will never be made permanent.  Actually, when you take a job at Chrysler remember to think short term, you should not stop looking for a another job. If you like what I've described, then you will do well there. They will really like you.

review_title: A far cry from what it was when I joined 20 years ago.
job_title: Engineering Specialist in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: More opportunities to work a variety of projects, and improve skills. Depending on the department, and immediate management, work-life balance can be good. Nice facility, with almost everything under one roof.
cons: Best way to advance your career is to avoid telling the truth. Nobody wants to hear your honest appraisal of the problem. Generally, minimal emphasis on technical and engineering skills. Lately, company has been on a hiring spree. Performance evaluation system is a joke, meant to reward the people who tow the line.

pros:
- The work environment is great. Most people are excellent team players and is really easy and enjoyable working with them.
- I have never had better managers than in FCA, they really care for your career growth. 
- The balance between work and personal life is great, they really respect your private time. 
- FCA is full of knowledgeable people so you can speed up your learning curve. 
- The mobility within FCA is good, if you decide to take a different career path is possible to interview with different groups and eventually move.
- if you devote a few time to be part of the ERG's your internal network can grow exponentially.
- The benefit package is very competitive.
cons:
- One of the downsides is that the pay is average at best. Getting a raise is almost impossible once you negotiated your initial salary.
- The career path is almost non-existent you need a LOT of effort to forge your own.

review_title: "Chrysler Future uncertain.  Employees fear for jobs as upper management works in secrecy."
job_title: Product Development Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Creative Colleagues, a lot of responsibility, great products (at one time).  While at Chrysler, I had the opportunity to work on some great products with great colleagues.  In fact, I miss the product and former colleagues the most about my previous position.  There were just better opportunities for me outside of Chrysler.
cons: * No 401K, * No Education reimbursement, * Unknown future, * Upper management too hush hush with plans, * Major brain drain.  The human resources group at Chrysler is unbeleivable.  They hire in talent, but then fail to keep them because of lack of promotional opportunities, low morale, and the uncertain future.

review_title: Great place to work - depending on the department
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: It is a great place to work with amazing people, and a challenging environment. It also can provide you a good work-life balance. If you're willing to find your way into new areas and teams and don't care for growing at a slow pace, this is the right place for you.
cons: All the Pros only depend on which area you work on. Many departments are still very focused on following old processes and do not allow young people to express their opinions, or get any career growth, or plan for development.

pros: Benefits and pay, not much else.
cons: Many... lack of information, no incremental pay raises for salary, layoffs, poor senior leadership. I cannot emphasis enough find another place to work.

review_title: Good place to begin a Mechanical Engineering career. Company allows you to make your job what you want it to be.
pros:
Collaborative, learning, flexible work culture at most times
You can approach anyone to ask technical questions
Excellent diversity in the workplace
CTC has great potential, can become the Googleplex of the Auto world
cons:
Some teams are not motivated to thoroughly root case issues
Hiring practices are ordinary at best, hence half baked talent comes in
Mid-managers lack creativity and inspiration
A disciplined problem solving strategy is lacking (cross-functional teams should develop and breed experimental understanding attitude)

review_title: A challenging and fulfilling experience, great working conditions, fullfilling but very demanding  and long hours.

cons: Current leadership and competitive challenges are very demanding. That's the price of entry for success in this business. They make sure you know that part time employees and full-time employees are NOT equal and that is evident especially with not having vacation time, tuition reimbursement, paid time off or profit sharing,  vision,dental or prescription coverage.  Under the new contract.... There is NO pension or cost of living so my advice to you would be,  At one point,  getting into the "BIG THREE" was a dream job but those days are long gone.  My advice... GO TO SCHOOL!

Male dominated culture.

They don't give raises, for at least 10 years now, so make sure your starting rate is what you want till retirement. No pensions. Every other company uses buyouts to achieve this, but FCA just walks these guys to the door. Their pension funds for the golden age few are only 55% funded. It's incredibly mismanaged. The smarter younger engineers just quit and leave, and they can't seem to figure out why.

review_title: Poor work culture in SEBC Sales

review_title: If you want to be a difference maker in a Company - Go somewhere else
job_title: Finance Manager in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: It all depends on the department and who your manager is. A good manager can make your life better by helping drive the department to value added work. The benefits are good, the people are good (for the most part) and the highest levels of management seem like they do care about the people. Work life balance is not that bad. Most teams get 2 work from home days a month or ability to accumulate extra time off. Last week of the year is off between Christmas and New Years for plant shut down. Jeans are a normal for Friday's and only the old timers wear suits or ties. I've been in meetings were VP and CFO were wearing tennis shoes, jeans and a 1/4 zip. There is plenty of opportunity to move around and experience new areas or pad your resume, depending on what you want. Big company, so they pay for alot of nice things or help assist in classes. Like CPE credits, Six Sigma classes, harvard business classes.
cons:
Some middle leadership shield the truth of what employees think to senior leadership which prevents the higher up managers from really making a change to culture. The company is still very political. The promotions are based on political factors, not your experience or ability. They FIRE NO ONE. Once your in, its easily two years of bad reviews before they let you go. They would rather force people out. Problem being , if your making good money and you are bad at your job, why leave if you are only working 10-4 everyday. While the good workers pick up that extra work, pad their resumes and leave for other opportunities. This leaves the company with alot of "waste bodies" or people who add no value. 

A major complaint of mine is that some managers judge you by how long your in the office. so they promote work life balance, but if your not in the office 7am-8pm everyday, then they just wont promote you. This penalizes the more efficient people who can handle their work in 40 hours. Alot of promotions are just managers trying to get rid of their bad seeds. If they have someone in their group that under performs, they will give them an average review so that they can get them out of their group. These people get promoted to roles that they have no business being in. Some managers, maybe 70%, have NO CLUE what their team actually does. I have heard managers tell me "I'll let this person tell you how this process goes because I am too far removed from it".  I worked in a group for 4 years where only 5 of the 25 people on the team were relied on. If someone left at 2pm, we picked up their work with nothing being said to them.

They talk alot about driving change, but when it comes time too, no one makes a decision. Everyone, no matter how little the decision is, just wants to pass it up to their manager, who passes it up to their manager. Lots of wasted time waiting for people to make decisions. You spend 2 weeks preparing spreadsheets and PPTs and then you never hear about those again. 

ALSO, VERY IMPORTANT**** come in at a high salary because they DO NOT adjust you for the job you move to. If you are promoted, you get a small bump. If you move laterally, you get a smaller bump or maybe no bump at all. They tell you its "good experience" rather than pay you appropriately. most you get is around 6%. With around 5-6 levels of management between the bottom and the CFO, it doesnt leave room for alot of "promotions".

review_title: FCA still trying to figure things out
job_title: Financial Analyst in Auburn Hills, MI
pros:
Please note that all departments, groups, and managers are completely different so the reviews will vary wildly based on personal experience.  But overall, I am in a fully successful team due mostly to our manager.  Our manager shields us from the politics of upper management and other groups and allows us perform our jobs without monkeying around in our business.  

Good pay, annual bonus, union vacation schedule, and great name recognition for working in a global company. 

Also, when FCA took over they cut the hierarchy in the management so even as a staff you are only 4-5 steps away from the CFO. Depending on your position and group, you also get very high exposure to senior management all the way to senior VP's and the CFO.
cons:
There are many challenges.  Starting with the fact many managers are promoted on what they have done and not what they can do.  They receive little to no training in people management and quickly get a feeling of seniority which they think entitles them to demean others and boss them around.  When something goes wrong senior management only goes to the manager and of course things roll down hill to the lower staff.  

Certain individuals in senior management have taken it upon themselves to find and correct these issues but it is a slow work in process.

The biggest complaint I here is work life balance.  It almost seems standard for most to work until the earlier evening.  It seems management confuses an employees willingness to work long hours as being equivalent to career drive and commitment.  This is a dangerous precedent to set. 

Typically improving processes is a good thing, however here is just means that instead of going home at a regular time you need to step up and fill in for others who can't do their job.

The big issue is the lack of internal communication which leads to many fire drills and stressful situations. Usually, these fire drills are the result of employee turnover and the new employees don't know what needs to be done until after the fact.  This is where managers need to step in and help but that happens few and far between.  

Overall though, some in management recognize there is a problem and are trying to fix it.  I would definitely recommend giving FCA a shot for the potential they have as a company.

review_title: pays the bills, not a dream job
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Auburn Hills, MI
pros:
(with regard to FCA Design)

Good pay

Great place for walking! It’s about a mile, if you walk all 3 corridors. They are sunny and carpeted, lots of escalators- it looks very much like a mall. There is also a trail through woods (about a mile?).

The design director, Ralph, is very "down-to-earth", one of the people. People, in general, are cordial, polite and friendly. There isn't a noticeable hierarchy of direct and contract hires.
cons:
With regard to all the things I see that could be fixed, there is a general attitude of “that’s just the way it is here”.  People accept problems without trying to make things better or even see improvement as a possibility.

A major con I see is that the computer hardware is old and slow and the software is limited to what you request and are approved for, which sometimes takes months to receive. The quality of visual work is much lower than other design facilities where I’ve worked and I’m sure it’s due in part to these limitations. The monitors are on their “last legs” and nothing is color calibrated.

There is a lack of communication and scheduling between design groups and in turn, a lack of respect for one’s time. My work flow is feast or famine. I have nothing to do most of the time and then a mad rush and an impossible deadline comes out of nowhere, with no warning, forcing me to turn in sub-par work.

Just like some of the other Midwest OEMs, there exists a network of nepotism and cronyism. Unlike the other design studios where I’ve worked, many of the employees don’t seem to be college educated. I am surrounded by terrible grammar and constant talk of drinking stories. It is very much an Old Boys Club with very few females and minorities.

Although I’d rather have a lax manager than a micro-manager, my manager seems to be riding out his time till retirement, doing the least possible amount of work possible. I have no idea what the other members of my team are doing- no meetings. I was never introduced to the other members of my team and had to do this myself. There is no excuse for this.

Parking is far, especially if you have a competitor vehicle- you have to park in a separate lot. It takes 10 minutes to walk from the lot and through the building, so that’s 100 minutes a week I’m not getting paid for.  There has been (most likely) intentional damage to competitor vehicles parked in these lots.

Zero career education / improvement or travel

Few perks. The vehicle discount is 1%, which is almost an insult. You have to pay to use the gym. I see signs in the building for massages, haircuts, but I don’t know the cost. There is a large cafeteria and satellite cafes- I can’t comment, since I bring my lunch. There are several Dunkin Donuts and Subway restaurants in the building, which is a statement for the Midwest diet and lack of healthy choices.

review_title: Exciting products; horribly antiquated HR organization & utter lack of communication
pros:
1) CTC is a city within a city....everything you could want is in the building
2) Exciting products...definitely the most fun of the Big 3
3) Cheap healthcare costs and generous 401k match (8% match if you put in 10%)
cons:
1) HR organization is rather pathetic. Lack of transparency in all compensation and bonus plans. $2,000 bonus this year is a scam....after RECORD results in 2017 bonus for management employees went from 110% to 82% of standard. There is no formula for bonuses...it's whatever Sergio feels like paying out. You don't even know you are getting a bonus until days before it's paid....they never share what the plan is based on, what the goals are for the company...hard to work towards a goal when you don't even know what it is! Interesting to note UAW workers saw a 10% increase YoY and Sergio received a bonus payment of 131% of standard based on publicly available information.

2) PLM process is a joke.....you don't enter goals until March and they are finalized by October. It take HR half the year to place 80% of the employees in the "5" box of the 9 box they use. On top of that....employees rated "5" only receive 90% of their standard bonus....they definitely don't tell you that when you start!  

3) In 2017 the vast majority of employees saw zero cost of living or merit increases. On top of this, it was never publicly announced until December within your group....2-3 months after it is every year. Record results = employees get paid less with inflation. Interesting huh?

4) CTC is getting dated

review_title: The Good, Bad, and Ugly at Chrysler....well, maybe not ugly.
job_title: Product Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Although not as wonderful as perhaps 10 years ago, the comradery and building are tops in the opinion of most people.  I've worked at all of the Big 3, and Chrysler treats their contract employees best; you don't know unless you look at the badge.  I've never known anyone having an issue with time off.  Some of my managers have been exceptional for granting time off for special circumstances.  I cannot say enough about the improvement in morale and positive outlook brought about by FIAT taking over.  The difference between them and Daimler is just night-and-day.  We most definitely have a partner now.
cons: The concept of "system engineering" seems to be lost on most.  Many old Daimler bad habits still exist.  Many engineers focus soley on their part (and it's cost) with little or no regard as to how it affects the vehicle as a whole.  Couple that with a drive by some to further their career, at all costs, and you have a recipe for disaster.  Unfortunately, many of those people are in positions which grant them the power to make decisions which affect the product.  Another astounding observation made by many is that anecdotal evidence trumps physics and data.  Countless times has exhaustive research, testing, or analysis been wiped-out by statements like "I don't believe that" or "That was tried before and it didn't work, so it won't work now."  No proof or data to back up these assertions, but they deal a fatal blow nonetheless.  Organization and common procedures are nowhere to be found.  We are in the 21st century and our ability to share and organize information within the company is beyond horrible.  We still have many sharp and bright people at Chrysler.  However, if there is no coduit or mechanism to channel that intellect, we'll go nowhere fast.

In addition to longevity and security, compensation at Chrysler is competitive if not better than comparable positions at other companies in the automotive industry.  Both those aspects of employment at Chrysler create great loyalty to the organization and to the products.
cons: In such a large organization, it is easy to become anonymous.  Even exceptional work recognized by your local management can be overlooked by the larger organization.  That means that those who do get ahead in the organization do so through political maneuvering rather than technical competence.  In an organization dependent on engineering competence, this shows most in the products.  When the leadership from the middle on up cared about cars and knew how to design and build them--as in the mid-90s--the public raved about Chrysler's products. review_title: Good pay and professional experience, awful management/leadership
pros: They pay you well right off the bat. Younger professionals or recent college grads will love the pay at first. Very hard to find a company that will pay their employees that have little or no professional experience that much money. Once you're in the field, you get a free company car, free auto insurance and free gas.
cons:
I appreciated the opportunities given to me and the experience I gained, but every employee frequently considers quitting throughout their time with Chrysler. Management treats you like dirt, very unprofessional and disrespectful. They way the majority of employees talk about minorities and women is disgusting and inappropriate. I can't imagine working for Chrysler as a woman. Your supervisors threaten your job on a weekly basis for things that are clearly out of your control. Forget about job security...there is none. If, for any reason, your supervisors don't like you, they'll make life for you a living hell until you quit (apparently firing people is a difficult process). They'll call you out in front of your peers and intentionally make you feel like a moron until you leave the company. You have no say in relocation...your expected response is "yes sir". They tell you to jump and you say "how high". Some very unethical managers within this company. 

Expect to work every weekend, holidays included.

review_title: Frustrating, but you can have a career.
job_title: Electrical Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros: Vast Automotive Environment - huge complex with diverse opportunities.  Every thing is under one roof, so you get to see the whole enchilada.
cons: Internal systems need improvements.  Management doesn't seem to try to streamline processes, they give that task back to you. Since we'll be absorbing Fiats debt, profit sharing will be low to nil this coming year.  Forget about the pension as we once knew it.

pros:
Iconic brands and products
Big company but can have input
Ability to gain exposure to a lot of areas (good for people who want to learn more)
cons:
HQ Turin control everything, no autonomy and you have to work around what they want. The UK company is dictated by Turin despite them not having the expertise of the UK market as local management would.

In contrast to the exposure gained, you don't get any increase for more responsibility unless you change grade and even that needs to be agreed by Turin.  The company has a policy not to increase salaries for "sideways" moves even if its higher responsibility or due to past performance. In some cases, they won't increase even if you've increased bands for a while. This is completely hypocritical of the CEO saying the company is a meritocracy. 

No inflationary pay rises unless it's a legal requirement in the country. The company will quite happily not increase pay, let staff leave and pay someone new with less/similar experience and pay more and an agency fee. The policy centrally seems that they'll wait until someone is so frustrated and resigns or is very close to before they'll acknowledge it centrally and consider doing anything. 

There's a lot of internal politics in the company and certain employes are favoritised for everything and their team has to put up with it. This results in highly talented individuals leaving the company due to the favourite employees calling the shots. I've witnessed countless highly talented people leave the business due to these people preventing development for people who could make the difference. 

Very reactionary business and everything is done after the market (e.g. one of the last companies to bring in an SUV). Everything is requested last minute and needed in the past but never communicated until later. Mostly from Italy HQ although that culture imprints to UK Management.

A lot of subsidiaries in the structure who are working against each other rather than in collaboration. 

Limited progression and internal opportunities not really communicated (unless you're Italian) which causes a lot of people to leave after 2-3 years.

review_title: A great place to work at, interesting projects, amazing HQ's
job_title: Colour and Trim Designer in Turin
pros:
Amazing working environment, very creative work, talented people with possibilities for professional growth.

I started as an intern in the company and was lucky enough to have a super manager among 3 in my department. My manager and colleagues would guide me through all the initial learning steps, but would also leave much space for personal initiative, followed by progressive assignment of responsibilities. By the end of my 7-month internship, I had already been leading and handling couple of projects on my own.

Among what seems to be out there for creative people in the EU, I consider Fiat to be one of the best places to work at. At least in the beginning of your carrier.

Creative people will have the chance to be constantly up to date with current trends, new technologies, new materials and everything that surrounds their work, as all the innovation starts from within the automotive business and spreads over to other professional fields.
cons:
For a company in the size of Fiat, they could provide employees with some perks, like in-house doctors or a gym, as the company is situated just outside of the city in an industrial zone and leaves little time for anything else after work.

Non transparent evaluation process based mainly on financial aspects and not so much on the progression of the employee. After my contract ended, waiting till the last week to see if they would renew it, I was informed off the record that from the moment they hired me as an intern, they knew they wouldn't keep me, no matter how well or not I did, because there was no margin for new hires by the financial department. All internships are financed by EU funds so it has sort of become a systematic approach to just hire a new intern every half a year and then let them go.

Complicated company structure.

job_title: Quality Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros:
It was called Chrysler Group, LLC. when I worked there. People always think of Chrysler as the smallest of the Big 3, and somehow this equates to a lesser quality product. I fell prey to this way of thinking, but my outlook completely changed once I was given an internship to work there.

I initially applied to Powertrain Product Development, but was instead assigned to Powertrain Quality. I liked the idea of working with the drive line, and accepted the offer. After I accepted the offer, the HR person in charge of the internships left her job, and the new replacement made a couple mistakes. Long story short, I was assigned to a manufacturing role (not what I interviewed for), but the HR department kindly moved me back into the headquarters.

I made a ton of friends in the Product Development and R&D departments, and they seemed to be working on their own project, within a very focused scope. I was stuck staring at Excel, examining issues for the minivan. One intern even said that he got to develop a new shifting knob for the new Hellcat Challenger. Didn't like my job, but I loved the creativity and innovation that really defines Chrysler. There is less vertical distance between the intern and CEO, and there were multiple occasions when I got to chat with Sergio himself. This is fantastic, compared to the other automakers.

CTC is one of the biggest facilities in the world, Chelsea Proving Grounds is an amazing experience, and they gave us interns a ton of professional development exposure, as well as really well organized social activities.
cons:
I had never worked in quality before, but in a previous internship, I knew that they were the nay-sayers of the company. I was optimistic, but it turned out that I was correct. My job as an intern was searching through a database of thousands of warranty entries, importing them into Excel, and contacting each of the responsible groups, to ensure that the problems would not occur again. Okay, seemed easy enough. What was difficult was getting people together to (1) take me seriously, and (2) deliver the level of detail that I needed. For those of you not in quality, my job was very dependent on the designers to give me the information I needed. My job depended on others being cooperative.

My situation was very dependent on my immediate superior, and I felt that he could have given me more stimulating work. I'm an OSU student, and he was a Michigan graduate, so that might have been the cause ;)

review_title: Good pay and benefits. Management inexperienced/incompetent.
pros: Pay is the best you can find in my area without a degree. Currently topped out at 19.28 and hour with 5% shift premium for working nights. 6:00pm-4:30am wed-sat. Decent amount of overtime offered as Chrysler sales have been ever increasing over the last several years. 3 bonuses paid out every year. Health/dental/vision insurance is included in your pay, therefore it doesn't cost you anything out of your take home pay. Stress is minimal as a line worker. Any time being laid off is reimbursed at nearly 90% of a 40 hour week. Tuition assistance available to you up to $5000 a year.
cons: Hours are inconvenient. Attendance is very rigid and inflexible. Being an assembly line you aren't able to leave early if need be unless it is an emergency... Even then it is not a given. Bathroom is limited to when your team leader is able to relieve you or wait til break. Vacation time is minimal. No sick days. Constant job eliminations, resulting in work constantly being added onto. Then of course you have the UAW which is notorious for supporting only the most frivolous employees. Also as a union worker there is no room for promotion within the company. Although I will admit if you attain a degree, you have a foot in the door to obtaining a management position. Most importantly the work performed is detrimental to the condition of your body. Especially with recent increases in workload, this is a job I could see working for a maximum of maybe 10 years while maintaining a properly functioning body.

pros: As a product engineer at Chrysler there are several benefits.  Often times you engage in hands-on engineering, with the  ability to work directly on or with cars and trucks.  Many times this involves driving and evaluating vehicles, including road trips.   You also have the chance to see new products years before they reach the market.  If you like project management, most engineering jobs involve a degree of this to ensure parts are sourced, tested, and released on time.  Engineers can also interface with various levels of management, something that may not be common at other large companies (i.e. engineers can present to vice presidents).
cons: Currently the company is not making money, and as a result, there are limited or no salary increases.  There is also limited career advancement at the moment.  There seems to be too much tracking and reporting in all departments, which detracts from the core business and requires much time and effort from the employees with little realized benefit.  As an engineer you are often a project manager, and the suppliers do the actual product design.  This can be somewhat frustrating if you want to be more engaged in fundamental engineering.  Interfacing with different groups can also be frustrating as there are defined "chimneys" within the organization, each with there own objectives.

review_title: A nice place to visit, but you wouldn't want to live there.
job_title: Product Engineer in Auburn Hills, MI
pros:
I know that this sounds clichéd, but the people are the best reason to work for Chrysler.  A Chrysler employee is someone who can do an amazing amount of work with very limited resources.  No job or obstacle is thought to be impossible by a Chrysler employee. Everyone there possesses a strong sense of determination in getting the job done.  There is a sense of pride amongst your colleagues at what can be accomplished and you are surrounded by very talented people that you learn from and work with everyday.  Over the last decade the auto industry has been a difficult place to work with all of the global competition, cost cutting and challenges that are present in this industry.  Chrysler's ability to survive the doomed merger with Daimler is directly attributable to the level of productivity that has been shown by the dwindling workforce and their resolve.  The spirit of working for a company that always has found a way to survive and conquer the next obstacle drives the organization.   

The base compensation is fair and the benefits offered are generous. A lot of paid holidays.
cons:
The auto industry is contracting and much more is being expected from each employee.  Now, this is common for many businesses, but Chrysler has been extremely slow in addressing these issues with tools to aid the employee.  Laptops,cell phones, flextime, offsite connectivity, internet connection at work and alternative work arrangements/schedules have been extremely slow to develop, if at all.    Management is done at a distance and blanketed across everyone.  Very little that is filtered up to improve operations is recognized or investigated.  No sense of entreprenurial spirit, except in the employees working around limits within the systems to get things accomplished. Impossible tasks are coupled with too little support and too few resources to remain competitive with outside firms.  

Management doesn't do an adequate job of setting up the organization for success.  Too many talented people are doing jobs that bring little value to the organization.  Simple reorganization of departments or deployment of specialized skills from those who possess them could provide so many benefits to the cost structure,morale, productivity,etc. that it is surprising that this hasn't been addressed. 

Too much is expected from the employee, yet too little is expected from management. At one point, a third party consulting firm conducted an internal survey which revealed that Chrysler was more than 50% understaffed for the amount of work required to keep current operations moving.  Chrysler has not been profitable for many years,however we still had senior management level mgrs. in the mgt. bonus structure (40% -100% of annual pay) reaping the rewards of a successful co. The subordinates of the senior managers typically went without merit increases, had increased annual benefit contributions and worked excessive overtime to receive an average rating on appraisals  This contributed to a strong divide between the working class and management within the organization. This was a big drain on morale for both salaried and bargaining unit employees. 

Short term thinking is the management style. Very little long range planning took place. Mgt felt that research and development can be purchased instead of developed in house. 

Many years went by where performance appraisal goals were not established until late in the fourth quarter of the year you were being evaluated on!

Forced two week vacation in July.  0-5 years experience have no say in how they use their vacation time. It is already accounted for. 10 years+ experience have 5 days that can be used at own discretion.

review_title: Chrysler Decides to Sink or Swim
job_title: Senior Finance Manager in Auburn Hills, MI
pros:
Great people with excellent work ethics!  
The product ideas are leaders and executed well when they are allowed to implement.  Now that Daimler has exited the building, freedom to create further product advances should stimulate market interest.  
The CTC complex is an outstanding feature for the company.  They have tried to incorporate many of the life-work balance items like hair, health, and medical under one roof.  Since most of the company is in one location, cross-functional experiences are fantastic and suitable for collaboration without extensive travel time.  Since the entire product development process is on-site, others outside the normal product creation process can participate and are regularly requested to give feedback.
cons: The recent executive management team has shown no forward thinking.  They have focused only on the currect conditions and given little thought to future viability.  Their lack of industry experience has been highlighted with recent exposure in Washington DC.  They have talked about product, but only shown what they think the public wants to see, yet put minimal efforts toward those products.  Few people actually see the new products and few still know where they are going.  This is not like selling hammers where cheapest labor is best.  The current product look/feel has shown how poor choice of supplier partners has hurt.

review_title: The "car guys" don't seem to want car guys working for them.
pros: Pay is great if you're just out of college. Benefits are also very nice. Your car insurance is super cheap because of company car discounts. If you're a car person, seeing and knowing about new products well ahead of time is awesome. You also might get a company car that's an all new model. This might be months before they show up on dealers lots. Very cool feeling driving around in that. I personally loved all the travel including flying across the country every now and then for the big meetings. I also loved how everyday was a small adventure.  It was Challenging and very rewarding at times. Always felt great to beat more seasoned veterans at anything.  Many great colleagues across the country to learn from and interact with. Many interesting characters in the dealerships. In my experience, five years of this job gives you at least double that in stories.  The best part:  if you're a decent person, you can really make a difference with customers.
cons:
Simply put:  the business centers run like bad dealerships.  Separation between sales and parts and service is very irritating. Sales area managers get more pay, more perks, better field cars that they often get to choose, more recognition, fewer (often half) dealers to call on, and the business center directors actually know their names. A parts and service area manager is known as "you" most of the time whilst being ordered to take notes or fetch coffee or something else that a corporate agent shouldn't be doing. Again these things are similar to a poorly run dealership. Through all of this you're told that you're equal to your sales counterparts. 
Very confusing "direction" from middle management is a daily occurrence. Most of the time it seems like you'll do better if you have no short term memory.  If something is the right thing to do today, it won't be tomorrow or perhaps two hours from now. 
Everyone's job is constantly threatened. This gets worse when it's end of quarter and you're called up to to one of the regional offices for a week. The subliminal as well as blatant harassment gets worse at these times. Through all of this you're still supposed to sell thousands and thousands in slightly discounted parts. 
Your district can make or break you no matter how good you really are. I've seen them even tailor a district to someone they really want to succeed. Then during your next sit-down they tell you how much better than you the person is that's been there six months. You'll receive criticism without suggestions for improvement at the same time. 
There is constant micromanaging. This is very abusive and the boss tells you you're making him do this to you. You'll get personal phone calls where they talk to you as if you are the cause of all the problems and only you. The funny part is if you call your colleagues an hour later, they got the exact same phone call. There is no honesty or positive motivation. The only tactic seems to be negative reinforcement. 
There were Loads of Sexist and racist comments including a few directed at me. If history is any indicator, HR wouldn't return my call about that either. 
HR is often the boogeyman.  My boss actually blamed them for a bad review I had. He claimed to have nothing to do with any of it. It was HR and the head of Mopar. Exaggerations and lies might pop up on a review. If they want you to look bad you will and vice versa. If you're a good employee, but someone doesn't like you, it's "Performance Improvement Plan" time. This has become more and more of a trend with them. It caused us to lose some good people. If you pass you're put on another. One guy I knew was on a pip for a year. I have also heard of multiple pips over years from others. 
Not many of us received raises or promotions really for 5 years. We did get a diminishing bonus system that no one really understood. If one did get a promotion, it meant more responsibility and stress...not pay.  Some of our people were promoted to doing what used to be three people's jobs. 
Every meeting and review is a beating and very adversarial. We had two people that could do no wrong. The rest of us were apparently the incompetent scum of the earth.  These beatings can lead to personal attacks. At the end of a quarterly beating, my boss concluded with "I just hope you're not disappointing your father."  This was in his fake sad/caring voice. 
In the end it was the sales focus that led me to leave the company.  There was less and less focus on helping dealers become more efficient and therefore create happy customers. We were all about quick parts sales. This is something we told dealers to never do or they could lose customers. This led to many bad deals. Dealers were promised things for cooperating that they weren't given. 
Through all of this, your expense reports aren't being paid on time. I was told that they would be paid promptly. That's in a nutshell what working relationships are like there.  Your immediate boss lies to you over and over because eventually you'll believe it. This is how they try to constantly manipulate you.  If he was mad at you...good luck getting anything paid. So then you're paying for the 1000 miles of travel expenses you do in a week. 
If you decide to leave the company, you have another fight on your hands. They tell you when you leave that you have to pay off your corporate card or you won't get your final paycheck...illegal. They also tell you you'll get your paycheck at the next pay period...you won't...also illegal. You have to nearly harass your "friendly" HR Representative to get it.  
My favorite part about leaving was the paperwork I "had" to (didn't) sign. Said papers were stating I agreed not to say anything unpleasant about them or try to peruse them legally.  They even said they'd fire me if I didn't sign.  It seemed a fitting end to all of this.

cons: The hours are insane bc of AWS, 70-90hr weeks at times, and they pay straight time OT, no profit sharing. Alternate Work Schedule as Chrysler calls this stupid system requires management to work 12-15 hr days. And they are lying if they say AWS saves money. Just creates mass confusion bc there is a gap between shifts so no communication. They refuse to hire enough supervisors to sufficiently do the job, so management gets worked to death. And they don't care, they will just kick your carcass to the curb and bring the next warm body in. Turn over rate is extremely high, I've never seen anything like it in my career. I've never seen so many people go out on stress leave either and it's due to the extreme amount of hours and work load. It's very easy to see what the problem is but this company refuses to acknowledge the problem and fix it. And with AWS, you lose about half your holidays too. So if July 4th doesn't fall on your day you work, you do not get that as a holiday!! What kind of company does that to it's people!! They do not promote people based on talent, they backfill people bc they quit from extreme stress or they move someone into a job bc the previous guy "couldn't handle it". Upper management is extremely disconnected from the amount of work load the Unit Leads and Business Unit Leaders have. If you try to put in for a job opening, they block you from taking it even if it's the direction you want to take your career path. People are not allowed to take other jobs inside the company, you are shoved wherever they want you to go and you aren't asked to go, you are told where you go. It's completely backwards from top level companies. And they try to act like WCM is part of the culture, it's not. World Class Manufacturing becomes important when an audit comes around every 6 months so they can get a score. Then after the audit, back to the old Chrysler. It's no wonder this company has been bankrupt and bought out 3 times in 15 years.

pros: Chrysler used to be a great place to work back in the 1990's. The CIE and the Engineering Graduate Training (EGT) programs lured some of the best talent to the company.  Unfortunately they have since reduced the number of CIEs (only from interns and no direct hires).  Chrysler has a hard time retaining CIEs and talent in the company.  There were also some good career opportunities in manufacturing operations, if you are willing to sacrafice work life balance.
cons: There are many downsides of working at Chrysler.  Chrysler has poor work life balance and does not support women in manufacturing who choose to have children (pregnancy and maternity leave).  There is too much personal vendittas and  too much politics.  In manufacturing, the management personnel are ruled by the union; management constantly tries to appease the union instead of doing the right thing, they do what is easy.  The manufacturing goals are  unrealistics and are set up to ensure you fail (unless you cheat); senior management awards bad behavior and as a result, the good people are not retained.  The bonuses the Sr Exec and COO/CEO recieve are not aligned with company performance...they get rich when they should be sacraficing for the company.  Lastly, poor production design,planning and execution/launch are a major issue at Chrysler as well.
